title: Smartphone makers say no to TV on your phone without data
summary: India's government proposal to mandate TV signal reception capability in smartphones faces opposition from major manufacturers like Samsung and Qualcomm. The policy would require phones to receive live TV broadcasts without using cellular data.
content:
India's government has proposed a new policy that would require smartphones to have built-in capability to receive live television signals without requiring cellular network connectivity. The initiative has met strong resistance from major smartphone manufacturers and chipset makers.

Industry giants including Samsung and Qualcomm have voiced opposition to the policy, citing concerns about technical feasibility and potential impacts on device costs and design. The manufacturers argue that implementing direct TV signal reception would require significant hardware modifications, including additional antennas that could affect the form factor of modern smartphones.

The government's proposal aims to make television content more accessible to the Indian population, particularly in areas with limited internet connectivity. However, smartphone OEMs (Original Equipment Manufacturers) fear that such requirements could create complications for their global supply chains and potentially make devices more expensive for consumers.

## Government Initiative
India's government has proposed a new policy that would require smartphones to have built-in capability to receive live television signals without requiring cellular network connectivity. The initiative has met strong resistance from major smartphone manufacturers and chipset makers.

## Industry Response
Industry giants including Samsung and Qualcomm have voiced opposition to the policy, citing concerns about technical feasibility and potential impacts on device costs and design. The manufacturers argue that implementing direct TV signal reception would require significant hardware modifications, including additional antennas that could affect the form factor of modern smartphones.

## Policy Objectives and Concerns
The government's proposal aims to make television content more accessible to the Indian population, particularly in areas with limited internet connectivity. However, smartphone OEMs (Original Equipment Manufacturers) fear that such requirements could create complications for their global supply chains and potentially make devices more expensive for consumers.
